comments:
I have about 1500 plugins in my PDE target platform. When I am pointing to this
plugins directory and I try to create a new Run-time Workbench launch
configuration, I get the following stack trace. I do NOT get this stack trace
when I point the PDE target platform to the eclipse plugins directory that comes
with M7. 

Steps to reproduce
1. Window->Preferences->Plug-in Development->Target Platform
   Specify a location with a lot of plugins, i.e. WSAD
2. Go to debug perspective
   Run->Debug->Run-time Workbench
   Click "New" button

I will guard against the NPE.
However, to be able to self-host using PDE, please point your target platform 
to the directory containing "startup.jar", i.e. the root install of your 
product.  These are the rules of engagement.

There is no guarantee as to what would happen if you point to an arbitrary 
directory containing plug-ins.

I'm am pointing the "Target Platform" location to the directory containing
"startup.jar"

The list of plugins in the preference page comes up filled with all the plugins
in that location correctly. The problem is on the launch configuration dialog.
You cannot create new runtime configurations, or edit existing ones.
Is there an "install.ini" in the same directory as startup.jar?

Interesting.
Dejan, I thought "intall.ini" was a required file in an Eclipse-based product 
so that the primary feature and default application could be determined.  Is 
that not the case?

We currently count on it being there; however, we should definitely handle 
cases where it's absent.

install.ini contains the default application id, as well as the primary 
feature id. 
While it is recommended to have this file, eclipse should start with no file 
present.


On a side note: this file will likely be deprecated in 3.0, and config data 
exposed in configuration/config.ini
*** Bug 53081 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
